page.title: 15WANSFORD RIVER BRIDGE
page.content: The river bridge at Wansford is a large, impressive structure with ten arches which span the river and the flood plain. Prior to the sixteenth century the bridge had been made of wood, but in 1571 a storm caused the river to flood the village and it caused so much damage to the bridge that it was decided to build a new one. Local stone from Toll Bar Spinney was used in the construction, but due to a mediaeval industrial dispute, the job was not completed until 1577 and this date can still be seen carved on the stonework. Today the bridge no longer carries all the traffic of the former Great North Road, instead it serves only local traffic and is not wide enough to allow traffic to pass, so at busy times queues form on both sides of the bridge.
